awd_abstract_narration:
Investments made across national boundaries create international flows of capital. These flows help to determine the health of the global economy as well as the economy of the United States. Economists have developed theories about the causes and effects of these flows. However, while the term 'flow' suggests that these investments move a single coordinated force, in fact the investments are determined by many individual decisions made by individual investors and investing institutions. This project will use very detailed evidence on a fraction of these investments to build a better picture of international capital flows. The project will also test theories about these global flows respond to US monetary policy and examine how this specific category of investments may have real economic effects on receiving countries and may help to determine exchange rates. This research will help us understand how US economic policies affect the global economy, and how the decisions of investors around the world affect the US economy. The educational component of this CAREER grant will incorporate these research findings into classroom material as well as specialized courses aimed at central bankers around the globe. As a result, the project will give us new results that will promote the competitiveness of the US economy.

The project has four main aims.  First, the PI and his coauthors seek to develop summary measures of global bond markets that are based on these detailed and accurate measurements. Second, the team will consider how global capital flows respond to changes in one country's monetary policy; by testing economic theory, the research will give us better evidence for how changes in US monetary policy can affect the world economy. Third, the project will investigate whether the specific composition of international investments helps to determine how the investment affects the country receiving funds. Fourth, the team will test hypotheses about whether and how currency positions affect exchange rates.

por.por_cntn:
I have substantially achieved the goals set up in the grant proposal. In particular, the grant has led to advancements in our understanding of global capital flows and allocations.

In a paper titled "International Currencies and Capital Allocation" published in the Journal of Political Economy in 2020, we established the presence of home-currency bias. This bias is the tendency of investors to overweight securities issued in their domestic currency. We showed that the US dollar is the one exception, serving as an international currency that most investors across countries are willing to hold. We show that the US dollar exceptionalism leads to a different capital allocation for US firms.

In a paper titled "The Rise of the Dollar and Fall of the Euro as International Currencies" we document that since the global financial crisis in 2007 the international role of the US dollar has increased, while the role of the Euro has decreased.

In a paper titled "Redrawing the Map of Global Capital Flows: The Role of Cross-Border Financing and Tax Havens" published in the Quarterly Journal of Economics in 2021, we provided a method and related public statistics for unwinding the allocations of capital made in tax havens. Over the last thirty years, tax haven countries have attracted a large share of global capital. While it is clear that capital is not used domestically in those jurisdictions, it was previously difficult for researchers to systematically figure out where the capital should be allocated. In our work, we document the growing use by Chinese entities of these offshore jurisdictions, especially to raise capital from large developed countries' investors. We substantially reassess the US-China financial relationship based on our new estimates.

In a paper titled "Exchange Rate Reconnect" published in the Review of Economic and Statistics in 2022, we document a change in the relationship between exchange rates, interest rates (monetary policy), capital flows, and measures of financial risk. While before 2008 the relationship was tenuous, it has substantially strengthened since then. We discuss possible causes of this change in observed behavior.

The research carried out in this grant has laid the foundations for several ongoing projects. Current projects explore the way China is internationalizing its markets (paper titled "Internationalizing Like China"), global capital allocations in the Euro Area (paper titled "The Geography of Capital Allocation in the Euro Area"), the way China uses tax haves to raise capital from foreigners (paper titled "China in Tax Havens", published in the American Economic Association Papers and Proceedings in 2023). The entire research agenda is reviewed in a survey paper titled "Global Capital Allocation".

The research supported by this grant has been instrumental in starting a broader research effort culminating in the foundation of the Global Capital Allocation Project, a research lab that I co-direct. See https://www.globalcapitalallocation.com.

The grant educational component has also been achieved. First, by designing short courses for policymakers that I have delivered to several central banks and international organizations. Second, by the development of an online teaching initiative targeting PhD students interested in international macroeconomics and finance.
